Text: You look tired, warrior. It is not safe here. A curse hit our town and the night changed.
One night the lamps went blue. The well water tasted wrong. Then a black mark showed up on doors. After that people got lost in their own streets.
That mark is the curse. It ties the town down. It makes you forget the right way and walk into danger.
Days before it began a stranger came in a hood. He talked like a scholar. He carried a brush case. After he left the mark appeared.
You are not from this town. The curse grips the people who belong here. Outsiders can still think straight. That is why you can help.
To break it you must find where the mark was first made. If you ruin the first mark the rest should weaken.
The first mark showed up by the old hillside shrine. People who go there come back quiet and scared. If you want a charm ask the Blacksmith.
Be careful. Keep moving and do not linger in the dark.
Then go with clear eyes. The curse loves hesitation.
I watch the road. The night went wrong and the town changed. You should not be here.
It started after sunset. Lamps went blue. Dogs went quiet. Then that black mark appeared on doors. In the morning people walked in circles like they forgot home.
I saw a hooded stranger near the shrine path. He carried a brush case. He stopped at the first gate and drew something fast. After that the air felt cold.
The mark looks like ash and scratches. It shows up most near the hillside shrine. When the wind dies the mark feels warmer than the stone.
I followed tracks from the first marked door. They went uphill toward the shrine, then vanished. Like the ground forgot them.
Keep to light. Count your turns. If you feel lost, stop and listen. The curse wants you to rush.
